Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Cariaco Basin Oceanographic Time Series Program
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide three more years of support to three U.S. institutions -- University of South Florida, University of South Carolina at Columbia, and Stony Brook University -- for the CARIACO Basin Ocean Time-Series, located in the anoxic Cariaco Basin on the Venezuelan continental margin. In continuous operation since November, 1995, the scientific goal of CARIACO is to understand the relationships between hydrography, plankton community composition, primary production, microbial activity, terrigenous inputs, particle and other fluxes, and other processes of element cycling in the water column, and how their variation is preserved in seafloor sediments. The program strives to serve the ocean carbon and biogeochemistry (OCB) and the paleoclimate research communities by maintaining an observing facility in the Cariaco Basin that provides core observations and samples, and facilitates researcher access to a unique, world-renown tropical continental margin setting.

A central tenet of CARIACO is that the data stream produced there aids in the interpretation of oceanic carbon fluxes and global climate variability. Understanding processes that affect sinking material is key to understanding the "biological carbon pump" and processes that transfer materials from the surface ocean and adjacent land to the bottom. Since the Cariaco Basin only exchanges surface waters with the adjacent Caribbean Sea above a shallow (< 140 m) sill, anoxia prevails below ~250 m. These conditions preserve an excellent varved sediment record that is used by the international community to study Holocene and late Pleistocene climate change.

The OCB community recognizes that we are approaching a "state shift" in the global biosphere due to interactions between natural climate variability and human activities. Ocean time series like CARIACO play a critical role in documenting and evaluating the mechanisms whereby marine ecosystems respond to subtle changes in climate. Indeed, the research team has documented dramatic changes in the Cariaco Basin over the past 17 years that reflect transformations over larger space and time scales. They attribute many of these ecosystem and biogeochemical changes to a northward migration of the Intertropical Convergence Zone.

Broader impacts: The CARIACO Ocean Time-Series owes its success to strong collaborations established with scientists in Venezuela, the US, and other countries. It contributes to development of a growing global observatory focused on measuring ecological processes and understanding impacts of large-scale changes in the Earth system. CARIACO is an IGBP-LOICZ program relevant to international carbon cycle and broader oceanographic research. By providing climate proxies that improve the accuracy of past climate assessments, CARIACO directly addresses the goals of the CLIVAR and PAGES initiatives of the World Climate Research Programme and the International Geosphere-Biosphere Programme. The science also helps understand socio-economic impacts of ecosystem variability, such as the collapse of the sardine fishery and catastrophic weather events seen in the last decade in the region.

CARIACO nurtures international scientific cooperation. Venezuelan funding for local scientists to participate in this joint effort is an important incentive to continue this program. CARIACO has had a significant impact on technology transfer and capacity building in Latin America, by providing regional scientists with opportunities to participate in a project that addresses issues of global relevance. CARIACO also exposes U.S. students and scientists to an international research community and to the cultures of the Caribbean and Latin America. The research team intends to continue proactive efforts to develop scientific and technical links between CARIACO, BATS, HOT, and various other OCB Program efforts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past 25 years, the CARIACO Time-Series Program has served the oceanographic community by providing monthly measurements of water column properties, ranging from microbial diversity to the composition and flux of material to the seafloor. These measurements serve as a basis for understanding the physical, biological, chemical, and geological processes that occur on a continental margin that experiences highly productive seasonal algal blooms and contains no oxygen in underlying waters and sediments. Continental margins have a direct impact on coastal communities via economic development (natural resources such as fisheries, oil & gas, tourism, etc.), as critical habitats for marine life, and as large reservoirs of carbon storage (CO2 uptake) on thousand-year timescales.  Our role in the CARIACO Program was to understand the ways in which physical mixing, water column chemistry, terrestrial inputs, and foodweb dynamics influence the composition and magnitude of sinking material. A secondary goal was to use these observations to ground truth sedimentary chemical signatures resulting from water column processes and further expand their application in reconstructing past climates.

The Cariaco Basin is a net source of carbon dioxide to the atmosphere, however this source has significantly decreased over the past several years, likely due to a reduction in mixing between surface and deep waters and biological productivity. Over the duration of the time series, nutrient concentrations in the deeper waters have steadily increased with specific nutrients, such as phosphorus, increasing at faster rates. This suggests that the source, composition, and breakdown of sinking particles has changed. Isotopic measurements of sediments indicate that variations in deeper water nutrients likely reflect larger scale climate fluctuations associated with the polar ice sheets and changes in North Atlantic deep ocean mixing (Dansgaard–Oeschger events). 

The Cariaco Basin is also an ideal study site for investigating how oxygen concentrations in the water column, and thus redox chemistry and chemoautotrophy influences marine biogeochemistry, especially in light of ongoing widespread ocean deoxygenation. Results indicate that an active microbial community exists at the oxic/anoxic interface and utilizes sinking particulate carbon (based on isotopic analyses). At this interface, abrupt increases and transformations within the phosphorus pool also occur, resulting from chemical reactions associated with a trace metals and this large and diverse chemoautotrophic community. Combined, results suggest that the biogeochemical cycling of carbon and phosphorus may change within oxygen depleted water columns in unexpected ways. Why this microbial consortium exists and their impact on carbon sequestration remains unknown.   

Given that there is no oxygen in the deep Cariaco Basin, sediments remain relatively undisturbed by biological processes and provide an excellent record of events that occurred in the overlying water column. Planktonic foraminiferal shells are particularly valuable for climate reconstructions because they represent a combination of environmental, ecological, and biological signals within their shells. Results indicate that subtle differences in shell shapes may reflect different populations or environmental preferences within a recognized species, and thus how climate signals are interpreted from shells. Furthermore, our results suggest that differences in elemental ratios within and among various species reflect surface mixing intensities.  This allows for a better understanding of how physical processes may have changed in the basin over time.

Ten peer-reviewed manuscripts and five conference presentations have been published since 2014 with the principle investigators from this component of the grant.  Three additional publications are in preparation for a special volume in early summer in honor of Dr. Robert Thunell, the lead investigator of this collaborative proposal who unexpectedly passed away in August of 2018.

This research provided opportunities for research, teaching and mentoring in science and engineering areas by supporting the doctoral research of two students, three postdoctoral researchers, and six undergraduate students.  All had the opportunity to participate in research cruises and learn cutting edge scientific techniques, such as mass spectrometry, species identification, and a variety of biogeochemical measurements.  These individuals further learned the value of team work and how to trouble shoot problems that arise when working in field versus laboratory systems.  Both doctoral students served as NOAA Knauss Fellows and are currently working in the Federal Government.  One former postdoctoral research is now an Assistant Professor at the University of South Carolina, Aiken, and another is currently a Research Scientist at the Geological Survey of Canada – Calgary.  Our current postdoctoral fellow is completing her fellowship and recently received a Yale Postdoctoral Fellowship to expand her research in Fall 2019.  Four of the undergraduates who worked on this project are currently pursuing master’s and doctoral degrees at other institutions.  One received a NSF Graduate Research Fellowship.  The other two undergraduates are completing their undergraduate degrees and have plans to pursue graduate work as well.  Note that all students and PIs were also involved in numerous outreach activities to scientific and local communities via teaching, public lectures, visits to local schools and community groups.
